Award.AwardTitle: CAREER:Developing Novel Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Contrast and Sensitivity Enhancement Mechanisms for Materials and Reactions Studies
Award.AbstractNarration:
Song-I Han of the University of California-Santa Barbara is supported by the Experimental Physical Chemistry Program to develop novel contrast mechanisms for nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) that highlight molecule-specific functions of materials and processes by targeted signal enhancement of selected fluid molecules. Two different approaches for achieving non-equilibrium nuclear spin polarization will be pursued and developed, presenting mechanisms to obtain different types of contrast. One approach, utilizing inserted or natural unpaired electrons in solid matrices for NMR signal modulation, has not been demonstrated previously. In the research effort, (1) the widely used Overhauser effect will be extended to a broader range of nuclei and molecules, (2) a better understanding of the interactions between nuclei and unpaired electrons in materials will be achieved, (3) flow dispersion, absorption and reactivity of molecules in porous materials -- difficult properties to study-- will be accessed in situ, and (4) light will be shed on the whereabouts of active sites in heterogeneous catalysts. Theoretical efforts, instrumentation development utilizing emerging, high-power, microwave technology and the integration of interdisciplinary knowledge will be employed to meet the research aims.

Novel contrast and higher sensitivity NMR as developed in this project will allow the exploitation of molecule-material interactions that are currently difficult to access. The developing capability to trace directly the transport and absorption of small molecules into porous media in situ is highly significant in a broad range of areas such as chemical reaction, biological function, drug delivery, and petroleum research. The educational project plan includes the organization of magnetic resonance based workshops and field studies for undergraduate and high school students that will give them the opportunity for hands-on learning about magnetic fields and how NMR can be used to learn about common materials in the environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project had a pivotal effect on launching the PI's research career, where its outcome can be measured by the high number of peer reviewed journal publication acknowledging this grant (>22) and intellectual and broader impact as described below. This project help establish Overhauser Dynamic Nuclear Polarization (ODNP) as a novel biophysical tool that allows the measurement of the hydration water layer dynamics around proteins and lipid membrane systems with site specificity, while fully immersed in bulk water--a novel capability. This enabled the measurement of weak and transient interactions between proteins and lipid membranes that were not detectable before, or the characterization of early protein conformational changes. The visualization of these processes are fundamental to the understanding of important function and processes of proteins and membrane systems. This project also established the ODNP-induced hyperpolarized water as a novel, contrast-agent free, contrast agent for magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) application with enhanced contrast for flow phenomena. Finally, this project help establish novel approaches for solid state dynamic nuclear polarization (DNP) studies of the microstructure of heterogeneous materials, including polymers and semiconductors.

The intellectual merit of the project was that (1) the known principle of the Overhauser DNP effect was newly invented for entirely new applications, of studying the hydration dynamics of biological water and enhanced MRI flow contrast, (2) a better understanding of the interactions between nuclei and unpaired electrons in solution and materials was obtained, and (4) a set of solid state DNP instruments and methods developed that will shed light on the whereabouts of defect or other paramagnetic sites in a wide range of semiconductor materials.

The broader impact of the proposed development is that protein interactions key to disease or other important functions will become accessible with higher sensitivity; that enhanced MRI contrast can be achieved impacting the study of chemical processes of industrial applications, as well as the study of blood perfusion with enhanced flow contrast for biomedical applications, especially for brain perfusion imaging; and that improved processing methods for amorphous silicon may be developed that make this solar cell materials less prone to photodegradation processes. The broader impact on the education of graduate and undergraduate students were also profound. 3 PhD students participating in this studies graduated already, and 1 more PhD student will graduate soon. More than 20 undergraduate students were involved in research studies as part of this project, all of whom successfully went on the graduate school, profesional schools or the industry.
